namespace types
Summary
Variables
String_BaseA base struct for string class.

Variables

String_Base

template<typename T> struct String_Base {}

A base struct for string class.  The string then specializes for T == char.

String_Base

template<> struct String_Base<char>

A char specialization for String_Base class.  It’s later typedef’d, so it’s just “string”.

This provides a RAII string container that internally uses char*, but automatically manages the memory and provides some other neat features as well, like easy formatting.

Use this when working with char* is too complicated.

Types
StringDefined as String_Base<char>.

Constants

npos

This is a constant of the largest value size_t type can have.  It’s used mostly as “not found” return value.

Types

it

Iterator typedef, a char*.

cit

Const iterator typedef, a const char*.

rit

Reverse iterator typedef, a <Reverse> < it >.

vrit

Const reverse iterator typedef, a <Reverse> < cit >.

Functions

String_Base

String_Base(const char *str =  ""): p_buf(NULL), p_length(0), p_capacity(0)

A constructor that creates the string from const char pointer.  It simply calls the assignment overload.

String_Base

String_Base(const String_Base &str): p_buf(NULL), p_length(0), p_capacity(0)

A constructor that creates the string from another string.  It simply calls the assignment overload.

String_Base

~String_Base()

Deletes the buffer.

=

String_Base& operator=(const String_Base &str)

Assignment operator overriden to assign current contents from a given string.  Self-assignment is ignored.

If the current capacity is big enough, new buffer won’t be allocated and instead, existing one will be used.

=

String_Base& operator=(const char *str)

Assignment operator overriden to assign current contents from a given const char pointer.

If the current capacity is big enough, new buffer won’t be allocated and instead, existing one will be used.

=

String_Base& operator=(char c)

Assignment operator overriden to assign current contents from a given character.  Self-assignment is ignored.

If the current capacity is big enough, new buffer won’t be allocated and instead, existing one will be used.

begin

it begin()

Returns a pointer to the buffer.

begin

cit begin() const

Returns a const pointer to the buffer.

rbegin

rit rbegin()

Returns a <reverse> iterator to end.

rbegin

crit rbegin() const

Returns a const <reverse> iterator to end.

end

it end()

Returns a pointer to the string end (‘\0’).

end

cit end() const

Returns a const pointer to the string end (‘\0’).

rend

rit rend()

Returns a <reverse> iterator to begin.

rend

crit rend() const

Returns a const <reverse> iterator to begin.

get_buf

const char *get_buf() const

Returns the internal buffer as const char pointer.

resize

void resize(size_t new_len)

Resizes the string to be of the given capacity.  If the new capacity is smaller than the current length, the string will be truncated.

clear

void clear()

Deletes the string buffer and sets the length and the capacity to 0.

length

size_t length() const

Returns the string length.

capacity

size_t capacity() const

Returns the string capacity.

is_empty

bool is_empty() const

Returns true if the string is empty, false otherwise.

[]

char& operator[](size_t idx)

Returns a reference to the character on the given index.  Used for assignment.

[]

const char& operator[](size_t idx) const

Returns a const reference to the character on the given index.  Used for reading.

at

char& at(size_t idx)

Returns a reference to the character on the given index.  Used for assignment.

at

const char& at(size_t idx) const

Returns a const reference to the character on the given index.  Used for reading.

append

String_Base& append(const String_Base &str)

Appends a given string to the current one.

append

String_Base& append(const char *str)

Appends a given string (const char*) to the current one.

append

String_Base& append(char c)

Appends a given character to the string.

+=

String_Base& operator+=(const String_Base &str)

Appends a given string to the current one.

+=

String_Base& operator+=(const char *str)

Appends a given string (const char*) to the current one.

+=

String_Base& operator+=(char c)

Appends a given character to the string.

substr

String_Base substr(size_t idx,
size_t len) const

Returns a substring of the string based on the given arguments.  It will be a new instance with its own buffer.

First argument specifies the index to start the substring on, second argument specifies the length of the substring.

find

size_t find(const String_Base &str,  
size_t beg =  0,
size_t end =  npos) const

Given a string, this returns the position of the first occurence of the given string in the string.  You can also provide optional arguments specifying where to start and end searching.

find

size_t find(const char *str,  
size_t beg =  0,
size_t end =  npos) const

Given a const char*, this returns the position of the first occurence of the given string in the string.  You can also provide optional arguments specifying where to start and end searching.

find

size_t find(const char *str,
size_t len,
size_t beg,
size_t end) const

This is used internally by the two find functions above.  All the arguments are mandatory here and you need to provide the length of the substring to search for.

rfind

size_t rfind(const String_Base &str,  
size_t beg =  0,
size_t end =  npos) const

See find.  The difference is that it returns the position of the last occurence instead of first.

The position argument has the same meaning as previously.

rfind

size_t rfind(const char *str,  
size_t beg =  0,
size_t end =  npos) const

See find.  The difference is that it returns the position of the last occurence instead of first.

The position argument has the same meaning as previously.

find

size_t rfind(const char *str,
size_t len,
size_t beg,
size_t end) const

This is used internally by the two rfind functions above.  It uses find to locate the last occurence.

erase

String_Base& erase(size_t pos =  0,
size_t len =  npos)

Erases a part of the string, moving the rest of it back by the erased part.  The erased part is here specified by the position of the first character to erase and the length of the erased part.

erase

it erase(it position)

This erases a single character specified by an iterator.

erase

it erase(it first,
it last)

This erases a part of the string specified by two iterators, the first one specifying the first character to erase and the second one specifying the last character to erase.

vformat

String_Base& vformat(const char *fmt,
va_list ap)

Formats the string using a given format string (as const char*) and a va_list of arguments.

The format string is the same as with printf family.

vformat

String_Base& vformat(const String_Base &fmt,
va_list ap)

Formats the string using a given format string (as const string&) and a va_list of arguments.

The format string is the same as with printf family.

format

String_Base& format(const char *fmt,
 ...)

Formats the string using a given format string (as const char*) and a list of arguments.

The format string is the same as with printf family.

format

String_Base& format(const String_Base &fmt,
 ...)

Formats the string using a given format string (as const string&) and a list of arguments.

The format string is the same as with printf family.

!=

friend bool operator!=(const String_Base &a,
const String_Base &b)

<=

friend bool operator<=(const String_Base& a, const String_Base& b)

>=

friend bool operator>=(const String_Base &a,
const String_Base &b)
